sen.j: 猶子（ゆうし）とは、明治以前において存在した他人の子供を自分の子として親子関係を結ぶこと。
sen.e: Yushi is a system existed prior to the Meiji period where parent-child relationship was privately contracted as if other person's child were a person's own child.
Yushi is a system that existed prior to the Meiji period to establish a parent-child relationship with a child who was not kin.
sen.cmt: 翻訳が原文と少し意味が離れていたためと自然な表現にするため、文章を1部変更しました。
sen.e: Yushi is a system that existed prior to the Meiji period to establish a parent-child relationship with a child who was not kin.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ただし、養子縁組とは違い、契約関係によって成立し、子供の姓は変わらないなど親子関係の結びつきが弱く擬制的な側面（その子の後見人となる）が強い。
sen.e: However it was different from adoption; in Yushi system, the parent-child relationship was weak－the relation was made under a contract, and the surname of the child was not changed and the rest－with strong pseudo color (like becoming a godfather of the child).

Unlike adoption, however, Yushi was based on a contract and had a weak connection, and a child's surname was not changed, so it was rather a fictitious parent-child relationship (in which a parent became guardian in many cases).
sen.cmt: 原文の語順と違って翻訳されているので、文を一部変更しました。擬制的の訳をpseudo color → fictitiousに変更、後見人をguardianに変更
sen.e: Unlike adoption, however, Yushi was based on a contract and had a weak connection, and a child's surname was not changed, so it was rather a fictitious parent-child relationship (in which a parent became guardian in many cases).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 元は古代中国において兄弟の子を指したともいわれている。
sen.e: It is said that the word Yushi originally meant a child of siblings in China.
It is said that the word Yushi originally meant a child of siblings in the ancient China.
sen.cmt: 古代 訳抜けのためancientを追加しました。
sen.e: It is said that the word Yushi originally meant a child of siblings in the ancient China.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 記録上に残る最も古いケースは源定が淳和天皇の猶子になったことであると言われているが、平安時代後期までは猶子と養子の違いは明確ではなかったと言われている。
sen.e: The oldest case on the record was said to be that of MINAMOTO no Sadamu who became the Yusi of Emperor Junna, but till the late Heian period the difference between Yushi and adoption is believed to be not so clear.

The oldest record of Yushi was allegedly the one of MINAMOTO no Sadamu who became the Yushi of Emperor Junna, but the difference between Yushi and Yoshi (adoption) is said to be not so clear until the late Heian period.
sen.cmt: 英語表現を一部変更しました。
sen.e: The oldest record of Yushi was allegedly the one of MINAMOTO no Sadamu who became the Yushi of Emperor Junna, but the difference between Yushi and Yoshi (adoption) is said to be not so clear until the late Heian period.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 貞観_(日本)14年10月10日_(旧暦)の右大臣藤原基経（藤原長良の子）の上表文に自分が叔父である故藤原良房（元摂政太政大臣）の猶子であったことが記されている。
sen.e: It was written on a Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor), on November 18, 872, of FUJIWARA no Mototsune－who was then the Minister of the Right and a child of FURIWARA no Nagara－that he was the Yushi of late FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa (ex-Sessho Daijo daijin [ex-Regent and the Grand Minister]); Yoshifusa did not have other child and his privilege of Oni (an automatic promotion system in which an Imperial title are conferred) and the family property were inherited to Mototsune, therefore today this is regarded as not Yushi but an adoption.

It was written in a Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) dated November 18, 872 of FUJIWARA no Mototsune, who was then the Minister of the Right and a child of FURIWARA no Nagara, that he was the Yushi of his uncle, late FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa (former Sessho Daijo daijin [Regent and the Grand Minister])
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処で文のセミコロン以下の文章を下のセルに移動しました。叔父である 訳抜けex → formerに変更しました。
sen.e: It was written in a Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor) dated November 18, 872 of FUJIWARA no Mototsune, who was then the Minister of the Right and a child of FURIWARA no Nagara, that he was the Yushi of his uncle, late FUJIWARA no Yoshifusa (former Sessho Daijo daijin [Regent and the Grand Minister])
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、良房に他に男子はなく、蔭位と家産は基経に継がれていることから今日では養子と解されている。
sen.e: But Yoshifusa did not have other son and the privilege of Oni (an automatic promotion system in which an Imperial title are conferred) and the family property were inherited by Mototsune, therefore today it is regarded as Yoshi (adoption), not Yushi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処（原文に「しかし」を追加しました）男子 childをsonに訂正しました。
sen.e: But Yoshifusa did not have other son and the privilege of Oni (an automatic promotion system in which an Imperial title are conferred) and the family property were inherited by Mototsune, therefore today it is regarded as Yoshi (adoption), not Yushi.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、具平親王の子・源師房は源氏の姓のまま姉婿である関白藤原頼通の猶子になったが、当時の記録では「異姓の養子」（『小右記』）と書かれている。
sen.e: And also, MINAMOTO no Morofusa (a child of Imperial Prince Tomohira) became the Yushi of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, who was the husband of his older sister and Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and never changed his surname, but according to a record of that time he was written as the `adopted child with different surname` ("Shoyuki"[the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke]).

Furthermore, MINAMOTO no Morofusa (a child of Imperial Prince Tomohira) became the Yushi of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, who was the husband of his older sister and Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) with his surname of Minamoto unchanged, but the record of that time described him as the "adopted child with different surname" ("Shoyuki"[the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke]).
sen.cmt: he was writtenは不自然なため、described him as に変更しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, MINAMOTO no Morofusa (a child of Imperial Prince Tomohira) became the Yushi of FUJIWARA no Yorimichi, who was the husband of his older sister and Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) with his surname of Minamoto unchanged, but the record of that time described him as the "adopted child with different surname" ("Shoyuki"[the diary of FUJIWARA no Sanesuke]).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、藤原邦綱の子の平清邦のように平清盛の猶子になってそのまま平氏に姓を改めた例もある。
sen.e: Another case was TAIRA no Kiyokuni who was the child of FUJIWARA no Kunitsuna and became the Yushi of TAIRA no Kiyomori, then changed his surname to TAIRA as if it was the way things should be.
Another case was TAIRA no Kiyokuni who was the child of FUJIWARA no Kunitsuna, became the Yushi of TAIRA no Kiyomori, and then changed his surname to TAIRA.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には養子との区別が明確化して武士や僧侶の間にも広まっていった。
sen.e: In the Kamakura period, the difference between Yushi and an adopted child became clear and this practice was widely spread even among samurai and Buddhist monks; (however in later years there were some cases where a parent had no real child and Yushi became heir－but these are understood as exceptions.

sen.j: 1．の代表例としては、足利義満の猶子となった満済や皇位継承の箔付けのために後小松上皇の猶子となった伏見宮彦仁王（後花園天皇）、そして近衛前久の猶子として関白に就任した豊臣秀吉などがあげられる。
sen.e: As the typical cases of 1., the following cases－Mansai who became the Yushi of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, Prince Hikohito of Fushimi no miya (Emperor GoHanazono) who became the Yushi of the retired Emperor Gokomatsu in order to add dignity for his succession to the Imperial Throne, and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI who became Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) as the Yushi of Sakihisa KONOE－can be pointed out.

The typical examples of 1. include Mansai who became the Yushi of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, Prince Hikohito of Fushimi no miya (Emperor Gohanazono) who became the Yushi of the retired Emperor Gokomatsu in order to add dignity for his succession to the Imperial Throne, and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI who became Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) as the Yushi of Sakihisa KONOE.

sen.j: 2．の代表例としては、藤原能信の猶子として後三条天皇に入内して白河天皇を生んだ藤原茂子や後白河法皇の猶子として高倉天皇に入内して安徳天皇を生んだ平徳子などが有名である。
sen.e: As the typical cases of 2., the following cases－FUJIWARA no Moshi who became the Yushi of FUJIWARA no Yoshinobu and married with Emperor Gosanjo to give birth to Emperor Shirakawa, and TAIRA no Tokuko who became the Yushi of the Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa and married with Emperor Takakura to give birth to Emperor Antoku－were famous.

sen.e: FUJIWARA no Yorinaga who became the Yushi of his older brother FUJIWARA no Tadamichi but fought with this very brother at Hogen War, and Kugyo who became the Yushi of his uncle, MINAMOTO no Sanetomo, and assassinated that uncle were among the unfortunate ones.
